channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Europe Pitches Stability to Bond Investors Wary of US Turbulence
item.description: Finance officials from across Europe are touting their bond markets as a haven from US volatility in a bid to attract global investors rethinking their dollar allocations.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers and commercial buildings, beyond Tower Bridge, in the City of London, UK, on Monday, June 2, 2025. At least 10% of the UK's wealthy non-dom population have left the country following tighter tax rules introduced by Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s Labour government, according to a new report authored by a former Treasury economist. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: US Stocks Fall as Trump Downplays Israel-Iran Truce Prospects
item.description: US stocks declined on Tuesday as President Donald Trump played down a potential truce between Israel and Iran. Traders were also preparing for the Federal Reserve decision on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises after a reported strike on a building used by Islamic Republic of Iran News Network, part of Iran's state TV broadcaster, in Tehran, on June 16. Photographer: Getty Images/Getty Images

item.title: Stocks Fall as Israel-Iran Jitters Spur Oil Rally: Markets Wrap
item.description: Renewed concerns about an escalation of risks in the Middle East and weak economic data drove stocks down as bonds rose, with traders gearing up for Wednesday’s Federal Reserve decision. Oil climbed.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump said Iran wants to talk about de-escalating the conflict with Israel. “They’d like to talk, but they should have done that before,” Trump said at the start of a meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney at a Group of Seven leaders summit in Kananaskis, Alberta.

item.title: Expect Eventual Pullback in Consumer Spending: Sriram
item.description: Barclays US Economist Pooja Sriram says a consistent slowing in the labor market, and price increases from tariffs, need to materialize together for consumers to feel cautious on spending. She speaks to Bloomberg's Lisa Abramowicz and Dani Burger on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Air India Salvage Crews Retrieve Second Black Box at Crash Site
item.description: Search crews sifting through the wreckage of the Air India jetliner that crashed last week retrieved the second black box, as they seek to gain more evidence to understand what caused the accident that killed all but one of the 242 people on board.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Mishra, Allyson Versprille

media:content.media:description: Landing gear at the crash site of Air India flight AI171 in Ahmedabad.

item.title: European Gas Jumps on Worries About Key LNG Route Navigation
item.description: European natural gas jumped as traders braced for a potential escalation in the Israel-Iran conflict and risks to navigation through the Strait of Hormuz energy chokepoint.
item.dc:creator: Elena Mazneva

media:content.media:description: Gas pipes and valves at a liquid natural gas storage and distribution facility at the port of Barcelona.

item.title: Markets Looking Through Middle East Conflict: Lovell
item.description: UBS Senior US Equity Strategist Nadia Lovell says markets will continue to look through the Middle East tensions as long as the US stays out of the conflict. She speaks to Bloomberg's Lisa Abramowicz and Dani Burger on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: India Regulator Finds No Major Safety Issues With Air India 787s
item.description: India’s aviation safety regulator found no major safety concerns with Air India’s fleet of Boeing Co. 787 jets during ongoing inspections following a crash last week that killed 241 passengers and crew.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Mishra, Eric Johnson

media:content.media:description: Planes fly past a an Air India Boeing Co. 787 aircraft.

item.title: Starmer Says US Not Targeting Steel Ownership in Trade Talks
item.description: The UK does not need to push out British Steel’s Chinese owners in order to cut a deal to reduce US tariffs on steel, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Emissions from chimneys at the British Steel Ltd. plant in Scunthorpe, UK, on Monday, March, 27, 2023. British Steel has proposed closing its coke ovens in a bid to overcome global economic challenges and build a green and sustainable future, according to an emailed statement.

item.title: How AI Drives Company Transformation
item.description: Bloomberg's Sonali Basak, Connie Leung, Senior Director, Regional Industry Leader - Asia, Worldwide Financial Services, Microsoft, Esther Wong, Founder & Chief Investment Officer, 3C AGI Partner discuss how they are investing to ensure the long-term continued growth of their businesses. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Illy CEO Sees Coffee Extending Slide on Ample Supply Projections
item.description: Italian roaster Illycaffe SpA expects the cost of coffee beans to continue to fall, helping to shield customers from further hikes following a run-up in prices.
item.dc:creator: Mumbi Gitau

media:content.media:description: Cristina Scocchia Photographer: Giuliano Berti/Bloomberg

item.title: Tech Investing Brings Outsize Returns
item.description: David Tsoi, Index & Research Development - APAC , Nasdaq and Rebecca Sin, Senior ETF Analyst, Bloomberg Intelligence talk about innovation on the Nasdaq (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Spain Says Power Grid Management Mistakes Caused April Blackout
item.description: Spain’s government said a nationwide blackout in April was caused by planning mistakes from the grid operator and a lack of spare supply from generators.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: An electrical substation in Burgos on April 28.

item.title: IMF Met With Emerging-Market Creditors on Debt Rework Strategies
item.description: A group of International Monetary Fund officials met private creditors last week in London, as part of the multilateral lender’s work to publish a new report on sovereign debt restructurings in emerging markets, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jorgelina Do Rosario

media:content.media:description: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank Fall meetings signage outside the IMF headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, Oct. 20, 2024.

item.title: Nassim Taleb Says Trump’s Approach to Tariffs ‘Makes No Sense’
item.description: The Black Swan author Nassim Taleb said President Donald Trump’s approach to tariffs will depress US gross domestic product and could soon lead to labor shortages.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Cantrell, Sonali Basak

media:content.media:description: Nassim Nicholas Taleb, senior scientific advisor at Universa, speaks during the Bloomberg Invest event in New York, US, on Thursday, June 8, 2023. The conference invites investors, from institutional and high-net worth to private and retail, to leave with fresh perspective and crucial insight for 2023 and beyond.

item.title: SoftBank Sells T-Mobile Stake for $4.8 Billion to Bet on AI
item.description: SoftBank Group Corp. raised around $4.8 billion through a sale of T-Mobile US Inc. shares, a move that helps fund the Japanese company’s grandiose plans for artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: A T-Mobile store in New York, US, on Monday, Oct. 21, 2024. T-Mobile US Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on October 23.

item.title: Fannie, Freddie Need Rules to Avoid ‘Race to the Bottom,’ NHC Says
item.description: Privatizing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac risks a return to the kind of perilous mortgages that helped cause the global financial crisis unless regulatory safeguards are kept in place, an affordable housing nonprofit said in a paper on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: Fannie Mae offices in Reston, Virginia.

item.title: Nassim Taleb on Risks, Gold, Private Markets, Trump Tariffs
item.description: Nassim Taleb, author of “The Black Swan,” and scientific advisor at Universa Investments, says he doesn’t think the “consciousness of risks” has improved over the last 25 years. He discusses the increasing US deficit, gold as a reserve currency, the opacity of private markets, and why the Trump administration’s approach to tariffs “makes no sense.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Swings as Traders Weigh Middle East Conflict, Weak Data
item.description: Gold fluctuated as investors tracked an escalation of risk in the Middle East and digested weak US economic data.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li, Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: One kilogram gold bars at the ABC Refinery smelter, operated by Pallion, in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Gold paused its record-breaking rally amid optimism over US-Japan trade talks, after bullion earlier reached another all-time high. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: Cathie Wood’s 50% ARKK Rebound Hits a Big Wall of Skepticism
item.description: Cathie Wood’s flagship ETF has staged a powerful comeback from the depths of the trade war panic, rallying more than 50% since early April. But rather than restoring investor faith, the rebound has only been met with skepticism.
item.dc:creator: Emily Graffeo

media:content.media:description: Cathie Wood, chief executive officer of Ark Investment Management LLC, during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Monday, May 19, 2025. We expect real GDP in the US to accelerate, Wood said.

item.title: Vale Base Metals Boss Says Unit Aims to Be IPO-Ready by 2027
item.description: The new boss of Vale SA’s base metals unit has reiterated a target of getting the sprawling nickel-and-copper business ready for a potential initial public offering by 2027, if not sooner.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc, Mariana Durao

media:content.media:description: Shaun Usmar Photographer: F. Carter Smith/Bloomberg

item.title: Qatar Asks LNG Ships to Wait Outside Hormuz Strait Until Loading
item.description: Qatar has asked liquefied natural gas vessels to wait outside the Strait of Hormuz until they’re ready to load amid escalating tensions in the region, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: The impounded Iranian crude oil tanker, Grace 1, is silhouetted as it sits anchored off the coast of Gibraltar on Saturday, July 20, 2019. Tensions have flared in the Strait of Hormuz in recent weeks as Iran resists U.S. sanctions that are crippling its oil exports and lashes out after the seizure on July 4 of one of its ships near Gibraltar. Photographer: Marcelo del Pozo/Bloomberg

item.title: Raw Sugar Slumps Most Since April After Previous Day’s Rally
item.description: Raw sugar futures retreated in New York, posting the biggest intraday loss in more than two months on an outlook for improving global supplies.
item.dc:creator: Dayanne Sousa, Pratik Parija, Mumbi Gitau

media:content.media:description: Cocoa pods grow at a farm in the town of Kwabeng, Ghana, on Sunday, Oct. 22, 2023. Punishing rains and the relentless creep of black pod disease push futures to their highest since the 1970s.

item.title: PE Firm Aurelius Is Said to Raise Over €800 Million for New Fund
item.description: Private equity firm Aurelius has raised more than €800 million ($922 million) for its new flagship fund that targets mid-market investments in Europe and North America, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Swetha Gopinath

media:content.media:description: Double exposure of business people who work together in office Source: alphaspirit/iStockphoto

item.title: Nassim Taleb: Trump’s Approach to Tariffs ‘Makes No Sense’
item.description: Nassim Taleb, author of “The Black Swan,” and distinguished scientific advisor at Universa Investments, says, “tariffs may be necessary in many areas,” but the Trump administration’s approach to tariffs “is not very rational.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Emerging Markets Slump as Traders Weigh Mideast Risks Before Fed
item.description: Currencies and stocks in developing nations extended losses Tuesday as risk appetite dimmed ahead of Wednesday’s Federal Reserve rate decisions as prospects faded for a ceasefire between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Zijia Song, Srinivasan Sivabalan

media:content.media:description: Smoke billows from a site in the city of Haifa, Israel, on June 16.

item.title: Oil Climbs After Trump Talks Down Prospect of Iran-Israel Truce
item.description: Oil rose as comments from President Donald Trump reined in speculation about a quick end to the conflict between Israel and Iran, keeping the market on edge about potential crude supply disruptions in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fanzeres, Alex Longley

item.title: Balkans’ Biggest Retailer to Refinance €1.22 Billion of HPS Debt
item.description: Fortenova Grupa d.d., the biggest retailer and food producer in the Balkans, has lined up funds from banks to help repay €1.22 billion ($1.41 billion) of debt owed to private lender HPS Investment Partners LLC.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Kuzmanovic, Kat Hidalgo, Marton Eder

media:content.media:description: A customer wheels a shopping cart through the aisle inside a Super Konzum supermarket, operated by Agrokor dd, in Zagreb, Croatia, on Tuesday, June 13, 2017. Croatian retailer Agrokor secured a new loan of 530 million euros ($596 million) from Knighthead Capital Management and Zagrebacka Banka d.d., a local unit of UniCredit SpA, in a bid to restructure its debt and continue operating. Photographer: Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: Diesel Prices Surge as Israel-Iran War Further Pressures Market
item.description: Diesel prices kept rising on Tuesday as concerns about Middle Eastern supplies — a consequence of the Israel-Iran conflict — piled pressure on an already tight market.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels

media:content.media:description: A person refuels a trailer truck with diesel fuel at a Petron Corp. gas station near West Port Klang, Selangor, Malaysia, on Sunday, July 21, 2024. Malaysia expects the move toward targeted diesel assistance will save the government about 4 billion ringgit ($848 million) a year, and has vowed to follow that up with unwinding blanket subsidies for RON95, the country’s cheapest and most commonly used gasoline.

item.title: Blistering Rally in Herbal Medicine Stock Mints $26 Billion Fortune
item.description: A blistering rally in a tiny, money-losing traditional Chinese medicine company’s stock has vaulted its founder’s net worth to among the world’s 100 largest fortunes.
item.dc:creator: Dylan Sloan

media:content.media:description: Traditional Chinese medicine cabinets.
